abstract: Statisticians and scientists are increasingly studying centenarians, with their numbers steadily rising; many of such older people shows patterns of health that are as surprising as they are mysterious; for example, rate at which people die rises steadily from middle age up through the 80's; but then, death rates decline; after age 110, death rate drops back to that for people in their 80's; photo shows six generations of one family, ranging from Sara Knauss, 118, to her great-great-great-grandson Bradley Patton, 3 (M)
snippet: Statisticians and scientists are increasingly studying centenarians, with their numbers steadily rising; many of such older people shows patterns of health that are as surprising as they are mysterious; for example, rate at which people die rises ...

lead_paragraph: EVERYWHERE, there is evidence of a life being lived. A futon has been crammed into the home office, used for a while by a pilot friend who was getting divorced. abstract: Editorial praises decision by Fairport Baptist Homes and other mostly church-sponsored nursing homes to shape daily life around needs and preferences of aging residents, rather than that of institutions (M)
snippet: Editorial praises decision by Fairport Baptist Homes and other mostly church-sponsored nursing homes to shape daily life around needs and preferences of aging residents, rather than that of institutions (M)
lead_paragraph: At a Roman Catholic nursing home in Albany a year ago, the order of Carmelite nuns that runs it broke from tradition by asking the aged applicants who were about to become residents: ''What time do you like to get up in the morning? When do you like to have breakfast? What do you like to eat?'' The Teresian Home had decided to end the tyranny of structure and schedule that herds old people through the day in nursing homes across the country: up at 6:30 A.M., dressed for breakfast at 7:30 to 9, lunch at noon in a dining room with scores of others, showers at a certain time, naps at a certain time, dinner at 5 to 5:30 P.M. and back in bed by 8, two to a room, on long hallways.
headline.main: A Better Way to Treat the Old
headline.print_headline: A Better Way to Treat the Old

abstract: Interview with Vivian Regina Pronin, who succeeded in persuading New York Health Department to change Medicaid regulations governing confiscation of Holocaust survivor reparations; photo (M)
snippet: Interview with Vivian Regina Pronin, who succeeded in persuading New York Health Department to change Medicaid regulations governing confiscation of Holocaust survivor reparations; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: WHEN Vivian Regina Pronin learned that her mother's Holocaust survivor reparations were, in essence, being confiscated by Medicaid when her father, also a Holocaust survivor, entered a nursing home, she set out to right what she believed to be an incomprehensible wrong. She called and wrote to lawmakers at state and Federal levels and to Jewish organizations. People sympathized with her, but no one offered to help.

abstract: Helen Best, 96, and two other disabled New Yorkers who filed class-action suit have won temporary restraining order barring city and state from discontinuing 24-hour home health care under Medicaid and forcing them into nursing homes; suit challenges rarely invoked law that requires Medicaid patients getting 24-hour care to prove that they have activities or responsibilities that cannot be met in nursing home; invokes exception in law for people for whom nursing home placement is medically unsound; holds forcing disabled into nursing homes violates Federal law protecting handicapped (M)
snippet: Helen Best, 96, and two other disabled New Yorkers who filed class-action suit have won temporary restraining order barring city and state from discontinuing 24-hour home health care under Medicaid and forcing them into nursing homes; suit challen...
lead_paragraph: On the surface, there are few more obvious candidates for a nursing home than Helen Best. Mrs. Best, 96, suffers from congestive heart failure, hypertension and dementia. She wears a diaper, has a pacemaker and is legally blind. In fact, under a rarely invoked state law governing Medicaid, she has been told that she must enter a nursing home rather than receive 24-hour care in her Brooklyn home.

abstract: Deborah Newquist is geriatric care manager in Newport Beach, Calif, occupation that did not exist when she received her master's degree in social work 24 years ago; field was born in response to nation's rapidly aging population and health care system's complexity; geriatric care managers, at $70 to $150 hour, generally do not offer hands-on care; part counselors and part social workers, they help manage health care, living arrangements and other affairs of their elderly clients; in doing so, they perform role once filled by families; photo (M)
snippet: Deborah Newquist is geriatric care manager in Newport Beach, Calif, occupation that did not exist when she received her master's degree in social work 24 years ago; field was born in response to nation's rapidly aging population and health care sy...
lead_paragraph: When an 86-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease broke her hip, Deborah Newquist was the person who stayed with her at the hospital here. Years earlier, Dr. Newquist had arranged 24-hour home care for the woman and her bedridden husband, and she also took care of everything from having their house painted to getting their cat to the veterinarian.

abstract: AS public health threats go, they could not have been more different. The West Nile-like encephalitis virus, which broke out in New York City in August, travels by mosquitoes that feed on infected birds and then bite humans. It tends to sicken the elderly the worst. The E. coli epidemic, which happened simultaneously in upstate New York, was food-borne. E. coli strikes the elderly too, but more often makes children the most ill. One disease, never before been seen in the Western Hemisphere, is in fact generally quite benign. The other is somewhat common, with the potential to greatly sicken many people under the right circumstances.    Yet ask around pediatricians' offices and the New York City Department of Health, and what do people fear the most? Hands down, West Nile. In recent weeks, the region seemed close to hysteria over the virus: Phones lit up in record numbers at the health department, parents in areas where there was not a single case kept their children indoors, TV reporters talked in stern tones about the plague among us. The E. coli outbreak, one of the worst the nation has ever seen, got scant media coverage and provoked little public discourse.
lead_paragraph: AS public health threats go, they could not have been more different. The West Nile-like encephalitis virus, which broke out in New York City in August, travels by mosquitoes that feed on infected birds and then bite humans. It tends to sicken the elderly the worst. The E. coli epidemic, which happened simultaneously in upstate New York, was food-borne. E. coli strikes the elderly too, but more often makes children the most ill. One disease, never before been seen in the Western Hemisphere, is in fact generally quite benign. The other is somewhat common, with the potential to greatly sicken many people under the right circumstances.
headline.main: The Nation; It's Infectious: Fear That's Out of Proportion
headline.print_headline: The Nation; It's Infectious: Fear That's Out of Proportion

lead_paragraph: During a routine physical, a 75-year-old patient named Joseph was surprised to learn that his pulse was highly irregular: 50 beats one minute, 140 the next, seemingly without provocation. He was surprised because, he said, he felt fine and hadn't noticed any symptoms, except for three brief, isolated periods of complete lethargy that had occurred over three months.

abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on dangers posed by carbon monoxide poisoning, and steps to guard against it; table shows effects on body of varying percentages of carbon monoxide (M)
snippet: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on dangers posed by carbon monoxide poisoning, and steps to guard against it; table shows effects on body of varying percentages of carbon monoxide (M)
lead_paragraph: You can't see it, hear it, smell it, taste it or feel it. But it can poison or even kill you without you ever realizing it's around. It is the deadly gas, carbon monoxide, and winter is the season it does most of its damage. Despite annual warnings about the many sources of carbon monoxide and how problems can be prevented and detected before it's too late, this product of combustion kills an estimated 2,100 people who did not intend to die and sickens 10,000 others in the United States each year.
headline.main: Watching for the Warning Signs of an Invisible Killer
headline.print_headline: PERSONAL HEALTH; Watching for the Warning Signs of an Invisible Killer

snippet: Holland Cotter reviews roundup of contemporary art from Berlin titled Children of Berlin: Cultural Developments 1989-1999, at PS 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: The last New York roundup of contemporary art from the eternally under-construction city of Berlin was at the Museum of Modern Art in 1987; it was all about neo-Expressionist painting. Now comes an update titled ''Children of Berlin: Cultural Developments 1989-1999'' at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, and there isn't a painting in sight.

abstract: Caroline Alexander article on visiting Lake District in northwestern England, home of poets William Wordsworth and his sister, Dorothy; photos (special section, The Sophisticated Traveler) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)
snippet: Caroline Alexander article on visiting Lake District in northwestern England, home of poets William Wordsworth and his sister, Dorothy; photos (special section, The Sophisticated Traveler) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)
lead_paragraph: With its dramatic hulking peaks and solitary valleys, its broad still lakes and mountain tarns, the Lake District in northwestern England is not only one of the most romantic landscapes in the world, it is also one of the most important sites in Romantic literature. This is Wordsworth country, after all, and it is from this district, at once so wild and so pastoral, that one of England's greatest poets drew his deepest inspiration.

abstract: Matthew Gurewitsch article notes New York audience have come to view Cecilia Bartoli as 'comic' diva because she played maid in three appearances with Metropolitan Opera; cites her performances in darker roles in Europe and in recordings; photos (M)t
snippet: Matthew Gurewitsch article notes New York audience have come to view Cecilia Bartoli as 'comic' diva because she played maid in three appearances with Metropolitan Opera; cites her performances in darker roles in Europe and in recordings; photos (...
lead_paragraph: HECK, she'd even play the maid to be in a show. So says the foot-weary Broadway Baby of Stephen Sondheim's wisecracking show-biz lament. As luck would have it, Cecilia Bartoli has played three shows in that great big Broadway barn they call the Metropolitan Opera. And every time, she played the maid. First came Despina in Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte,'' then Rossini's Cinderella in ''La Cenerentola'' and, finally, Mozart's Susanna on her wedding day in ''Le Nozze di Figaro.'' Should we be drawing conclusions?
headline.main: The Tragic Side of a 'Comic' Diva
headline.print_headline: MUSIC; The Tragic Side of a 'Comic' Diva

abstract: David Thompson article on reaction to Spike Lee's latest movie Summer of Sam, about serial killer David Berkowitz; focuses on Lee's remarkable, yet controversial, career; photo (M)
snippet: David Thompson article on reaction to Spike Lee's latest movie Summer of Sam, about serial killer David Berkowitz; focuses on Lee's remarkable, yet controversial, career; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: ''SUMMER OF SAM'' is misguided, reckless, grating. Yet it smells like the work of a very promising kid with a beautiful, perilous idea and more energy than he can control. And don't underestimate that energy, the life and the painful rawness. Because, to this viewer's eyes, they are so much more appealing than the mummified finesse that masks a nearly complete ignorance of human beings called ''Eyes Wide Shut.'' I know this is not what everyone is saying (in print), but it is why Spike Lee matters.

abstract: B Ruby Rich article on movie After Life; director Hirokazu Kore-Eda continues his exploration of memory as central theme in documentary-style film in which he asks elderly people what single memory they would choose to carry with them after death; photo (M)
snippet: B Ruby Rich article on movie After Life; director Hirokazu Kore-Eda continues his exploration of memory as central theme in documentary-style film in which he asks elderly people what single memory they would choose to carry with them after death;...
lead_paragraph: THE afterlife. Today it rivals Vancouver as one of the most popular movie locations. Ever since Ernst Lubitsch sent a departed mortal hurtling back to earth in ''Heaven Can Wait,'' heaven itself has been fascinating Hollywood. When Wim Wenders sent his angels earthward in ''Wings of Desire,'' a trend was reborn. What with John Travolta, Robin Williams and Brad Pitt all going celestial, heaven has never been more hip. Heaven help future historians tempted to interpret this era's spiritual proclivities from a close reading of recent movies. Luckily, they -- and we -- now have some help from the Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda. His new film, ''After Life'' (at the Film Forum) redefines our notions of what comes next in a charming fable that's as profound as it is simple.
headline.main: Choose One Memory to Take With You, He Asks
headline.print_headline: FILM; Choose One Memory to Take With You, He Asks

abstract: WELL, at least the movies are approaching the end of the millennium with a bang, which is more than you can say for the rest of us, the real-life inhabitants of this disconnected fin de siecle. But we still might turn things around if we heed the warnings of ''American Beauty,'' ''Fight Club,'' ''Bringing Out the Dead'' and ''Magnolia'' (opening Friday). On one hand, these are films about male rage, regret and reconciliation. But they're also like shock treatment, trying to stir all of us -- both men and women -- into leading more meaningful lives as we enter the 21st century.    Talk about eyes wide shut; these films are dedicated to the notion of busting up the numbing-down of society. Armed with gallows humor and the postfeminist mantra of male empowerment, they express the pain and anger felt by lost and lonely men and boys who are starting to fight back. But they also attack much larger targets: everyone's yearning for human contact and spiritual renewal that lies under these deceptively prosperous times. It's about time, too. After toying with our adolescent fantasies for so long, the movies are finally confronting our existential angst -- the real Y2K bug.
lead_paragraph: WELL, at least the movies are approaching the end of the millennium with a bang, which is more than you can say for the rest of us, the real-life inhabitants of this disconnected fin de siecle. But we still might turn things around if we heed the warnings of ''American Beauty,'' ''Fight Club,'' ''Bringing Out the Dead'' and ''Magnolia'' (opening Friday). On one hand, these are films about male rage, regret and reconciliation. But they're also like shock treatment, trying to stir all of us -- both men and women -- into leading more meaningful lives as we enter the 21st century.

abstract: Special report, Borrowers Beware, on growing trend toward high-interest lending in poor neighborhoods by big banks; banks are reaping high profits but many low-income homeowners are unable to pay mortgages; big lenders like Chase Manhattan, Norwest, Nationsbank, General Electric, Key Corp, Countrywide Credit Industries and others have expanded involvement in high-interest lending, which became big business in low-income neighborhoods nationwide after 1986, when change in Federal tax code gave break to homeowners who took out second mortgages; complaints have since mushroomed about unscrupulous finance companies that single out homeowners, especially many elderly with substantial equity on homes; suit against Bankers Trust and partner Delta Funding for allegedly violating Federal law prohibiting making loans based solely on equity in house and not on homeowners ability to pay noted; case of Gloria Knight, retired teacher who faces foreclosure on Brooklyn row house, which Delta salesman persuaded her to put up as collateral for $88,000 loan, discussed; photos (M)
snippet: Special report, Borrowers Beware, on growing trend toward high-interest lending in poor neighborhoods by big banks; banks are reaping high profits but many low-income homeowners are unable to pay mortgages; big lenders like Chase Manhattan, Norwes...

abstract: Third article in series, Life Death and Managed Care, examining year in life of three interns at St Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan who left medical school brimming with optimism and muted expectations but are struggling to find their balance in world of diminished resources and warp speed resulting from advent of managed care; Drs Jennifer James, Edward Lathan and Bryan Holland, infused with medical school idealism, have struggled to come to terms with hospital's managed care economics and protocols; their income has remained at same levels no matter how many patients they treat or how fast they treat them; to certain extent they feel encased in magic membrane that shields them from reality, being taught by doctors who are unsure how--and often less than willing--to teach for new medical world; from rush of their own experiences they are slowly adopting their own biases toward managed care; photos (L)
snippet: Third article in series, Life Death and Managed Care, examining year in life of three interns at St Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan who left medical school brimming with optimism and muted expectations but are struggling to find thei...
lead_paragraph: The investigators came late last January, on a Thursday. They were deliberately cryptic. All they would tell St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center was that they were looking into a possible violation of the federal ''anti-dumping'' law, which prohibits hospitals from refusing to at least examine and stabilize patients who cannot pay. It was serious business. Only a handful of cases were investigated each year. Not until the investigators left did the hospital learn what it was all about.

abstract: To the Editor:    An Oct. 3 front-page article discussed the use of bone-marrow transplants to treat breast cancer. At Memorial Medical Center, where I am chairman of medicine, these transplants are performed more often than appendectomies. In New Orleans, three hospitals operate expensive bone-marrow transplant centers, yet no hospital has a burn unit. There is no profit in treating burn victims, who are often poor and uninsured.
